blog.description: The Tumblr Home of the Weird Science DC and Marvel Comics Websites and Podcasts

summary: Captain Marvel #7 Review
title: Captain Marvel #7 Review
body:
Captain Marvel #7 Review

Written by: Kelly Thompson
Art by: Annapaola Martello, Tamra Bonvillain, and VC’s Clayton Cowles
Cover Price: $3.99
Release Date: June 19, 2019

I really enjoyed the first issue of this War of the Realms tie-in mini-arc because it worked so well as a team-up book that just happened to be taking place during the Event. Of course, throw in a Freaky Friday scenario and I will always be in as well!…

View On WordPress

summary: My religion: Marvel actresses
body:
My religion: Marvel actresses

Brie Larson? Goddess

Tessa Thompson? Goddess

Letitia Wright? Goddess

Zendaya? Goddess

Elizabeth Olson? Goddess

Zoe Saldana? Goddess

They are all FUCKING GODDESSES AND YOU SHOULD WORSHIP THEM

Thank you for coming to my ted talk.

summary: LEGO San Diego Comic-Con exclusives - Captain Marvel, and Batman announced
title: LEGO San Diego Comic-Con exclusives - Captain Marvel, and Batman announced
body:
Coming to @Comic_Con this year are @LEGO_Group exclusives of @DCComics @DCBatman as part of his 80th Anniversary and @Marvel’ / @MarvelStudios’ @captainmarvel. #SDCC #Batman #CaptainMarvel #SDCC2019 #LEGO

With Comic-Con taking over most of downtown San Diego next month, the announcements for exclusives are coming real quick!

This week LEGO announced two new exclusives for SDCC, the first being Gotham City’s favorite hero with the city as a backdrop, with the second being Captain Marvel and her Asis ship.

The Batman set has 427 total pieces, and will retail for $45 USD while the Captain…

summary: the universe awaits - c.d.
body:
the universe awaits - c.d.

in which a love story spans 40 years.

pairing: carol danvers x fem!reader

warnings: fluff to angst to fluff. this got long. also a lot of sexism but what did u expect it was the 90’s.

a/n: ah shit. here we go again. another writing challenge, this time a soulmate au! hosted by @mcuspidey ! i hope you guys enjoy!

“what’s a girl like you doin’ in a dump like this?” she’s trying to ignore the creep, with his beer breath and dad bod. she gets him the beer he asked for.

“doin’ my job,” she says, rolling her eyes.

she would’ve quit her job at pancho’s bar years ago, but danny pancho, the owner, was an old family friend, and let her keep the rv out back. nothing like free parking to make a girl stay.

“whatever, frigid bitch. get a real job.” he takes the beer and goes back to his buddies, who eagerly watch the interaction, audible groaning when she turns away and he has a sneer on his face.

sometimes she hates it. sometimes she loves it. and sometimes she wonders if the owner of the jet on her right wrist will ever wander through that door.

the tattoos are on display tonight—the plane on her right wrist, a bubbling erlenmeyer flask on the left. normally, they’re concealed, either by makeup or a flannel, but the day was sweltering and she had run out of concealer.

she occupies herself with wiping down counters—again—when a group storms through the front door, filling the low-volume atmosphere with yelling and laughing. she can only catch snippets of conversation from the group.

“-and the wall? that was-“

“-danvers on the ropes! a joke-“

“-rambeau even doing? no one in-“

“-laughing. like, do they even know-“

they approach the bar top, and her palms are starting to sweat. out of the ten to fifteen young adults, only three are women. not especially promising. with the way that some of the guys are looking at her, she wishes she could run back to the trailer and grab a flannel.

“hey, sweetheart, a round of beers for the guys!” one of them shouts, and she nods, throwing the rag into the sink and moving to the cooler, not sparing a glance at the group.

the beers are distributed and the boys are gone. she turns to the three remaining ladies. “want anything?”

“oh- uh, no, i’m fine-“

“oh, come on, carol. i’m paying. get something.” the oldest of the three chuckles, elbowing the blonde.

“i’m gonna get a beer.” her jacket has rambeau on the lapel—newly stitched. the leather isn’t even worn in.

“well, then, i’ll have the same.” blondie’s jacket is the same, she notices, but with ‘danvers’ written in white lettering.

she nods and grabs the drinks.

“not very talkative, are ya,” danvers asks, taking a swig.

“not really, i guess.” she shruggs. “cool jacket.”

she grins widely and sits a little bit straighter. “officially joined the air force today. that’s why we’re here. celebrating.”

air force. “you a pilot?”

“nah, they don’t let women fly. i wish though.” danvers laughs, glancing down at the bottle in her hands. “maybe someday.”

the conversation stays between the three women. she goes out back, confident that she can leave the bar alone for a few moments. she snags a flannel from her trailer, goosebumps rising on her arms now that the sun has gone down.

as she gets behind the bar, a sound of disappointment comes from the air force guys.

“oh come on, honey. we liked the tank top!”

she ignores them.

danvers rolls her eyes. “johnson thinks he’s hot shit. i think he’s compensating.”

“oh, yeah, he’s totally pissed that he’s not your soulmate,” rambeau replies, catching her attention. “i can still hear his rage from when he saw the flask!”

“flask?” she asks, catching the women, and herself, by surprise. “my mark is an erlenmeyer flask.”

carol soundlessly rolls up her right sleeve, and there it is. dark against her skin. a bubbling erlenmeyer flask matching the one on her left wrist.

“holy shit.”

—

four years in the air force, and her soulmate is dead.

carol danvers is dead.

she’s working at the johnson space center in houston as a chemist (one of three in the lab) when the news arrives in the form of maria and monica rambeau, paying a visit.

“the worst part is, the mission didn’t even exist. they were off book. no one will ever hear about it, no one will know her name.”

she cries herself to sleep that night.

—

the year is 1995. six years since the crash.

her work is monotonous, a distraction to get her through the day, to get her to forget her thoughts.

the thing is, when a person’s soulmate dies, the tattoo burns. it turns white. the black ink against her right wrist serves as a reminder that carol isn’t dead. she’s out there, somewhere, and she isn’t looking for her. she’s just sitting in a lab, playing with chemicals, watching as male coworkers rise through the ranks within months of being hired.

she’s depressed. she begins to loathe the universe for the cards she’s been dealt.

one night, she gets a call. he introduces himself as nicholas fury, from shield, and she’s suspicious. why would shield call her home without warning? and then fury says those words that gets her on the plane to louisiana within an hour:

“carol danvers is back.”

they reunite at the rambeau farm. carol hasn’t aged a day, but her face is carved with worry lines and bags under her eyes from sleepless nights.

carol thinks that she is more beautiful than ever.

“what the hell happened?” she asks her soulmate the loaded question, and carol launches into the story of her last 6 years. the kree, her newfound powers, the war, and the lies behind it all.

no one can blame her when she chooses to stay on the ground for this one (“space isn’t ready for me yet!” “sure, babe.”).

she comes back from lawson’s lab with a new purpose and unlocked potential.

she lets her go.

—

the year is 2018. carol has visited a few times throughout the years, but never long enough to settle down.

shield falls. sokovia falls. the avengers fall. again. and again.

half of the world is dust, and according to a trigger-happy raccoon, so is half the universe. 23 days go by. iron man is still missing.

she was tracked down by the avengers when they got back from wakanda, and they took her to their fancy compound upstate. they have fury’s pager there.

her heart sinks. if she hasn’t answered by now, there’s no chance.

but, for once, fate is on her side, and the blessing comes in the form of a beat up spaceship, a genius billionaire playboy philanthropist, a blue alien, and her glowing girl.

she cries out of happiness, and the group of heroes give them space to figure things out.

“i thought you were dead,” she sobs, and she’s drawn into another bone-crushing hug. her soulmate is here, safe, in her arms, and alive. that’s not something many people could say.

“i’m here, i’m here.”

—

the year is 2023. tony stark and natasha romanoff are dead.

she’s numb. she knows what loosing a soulmate can do to a person, and she’s sympathetic to pepper potts and morgan and clint. but she’s numb.

she didn’t know them well. she saw stark in passing, only introduced to him for five minutes before he retired, got married, and had a kid. natasha was a friend (if even). they lived together but barely spoke. they only saw each other when their schedules overlapped (read: never).

she is numb. and carol grounds her.

she is angry. if only a chemist could have saved the world. carol reminds her that not everyone can save the world.

carol reminds her that her world is safe, and standing right next to her.

she doesn’t know how the world will move on. but she knows that she holds her whole universe in her hands.

carol squeezes tighter. her universe.

her universe awaits.

—

tag list:

@defenestrate-yourself-please @limelight20

“-laughing. like, do they even know-“

they approach the bar top, and her palms are starting to sweat. out of the ten to fifteen young adults, only three are women. not especially promising. with the way that some of the guys are looking at her, she wishes she could run back to the trailer and grab a flannel.

“hey, sweetheart, a round of beers for the guys!” one of them shouts, and she nods, throwing the rag into the sink and moving to the cooler, not sparing a glance at the group.

the beers are distributed and the boys are gone. she turns to the three remaining ladies. “want anything?”

“oh- uh, no, i’m fine-“

“oh, come on, carol. i’m paying. get something.” the oldest of the three chuckles, elbowing the blonde.

“i’m gonna get a beer.” her jacket has rambeau on the lapel—newly stitched. the leather isn’t even worn in.

“well, then, i’ll have the same.” blondie’s jacket is the same, she notices, but with ‘danvers’ written in white lettering.

she nods and grabs the drinks.

“not very talkative, are ya,” danvers asks, taking a swig.

“not really, i guess.” she shruggs. “cool jacket.”

she grins widely and sits a little bit straighter. “officially joined the air force today. that’s why we’re here. celebrating.”

air force. “you a pilot?”

“nah, they don’t let women fly. i wish though.” danvers laughs, glancing down at the bottle in her hands. “maybe someday.”

the conversation stays between the three women. she goes out back, confident that she can leave the bar alone for a few moments. she snags a flannel from her trailer, goosebumps rising on her arms now that the sun has gone down.

as she gets behind the bar, a sound of disappointment comes from the air force guys.

“oh come on, honey. we liked the tank top!”

she ignores them.

danvers rolls her eyes. “johnson thinks he’s hot shit. i think he’s compensating.”

“oh, yeah, he’s totally pissed that he’s not your soulmate,” rambeau replies, catching her attention. “i can still hear his rage from when he saw the flask!”

“flask?” she asks, catching the women, and herself, by surprise. “my mark is an erlenmeyer flask.”

carol soundlessly rolls up her right sleeve, and there it is. dark against her skin. a bubbling erlenmeyer flask matching the one on her left wrist.

“holy shit.”

—

four years in the air force, and her soulmate is dead.

carol danvers is dead.

she’s working at the johnson space center in houston as a chemist (one of three in the lab) when the news arrives in the form of maria and monica rambeau, paying a visit.

“the worst part is, the mission didn’t even exist. they were off book. no one will ever hear about it, no one will know her name.”

she cries herself to sleep that night.

—

the year is 1995. six years since the crash.

her work is monotonous, a distraction to get her through the day, to get her to forget her thoughts.

the thing is, when a person’s soulmate dies, the tattoo burns. it turns white. the black ink against her right wrist serves as a reminder that carol isn’t dead. she’s out there, somewhere, and she isn’t looking for her. she’s just sitting in a lab, playing with chemicals, watching as male coworkers rise through the ranks within months of being hired.

she’s depressed. she begins to loathe the universe for the cards she’s been dealt.

one night, she gets a call. he introduces himself as nicholas fury, from shield, and she’s suspicious. why would shield call her home without warning? and then fury says those words that gets her on the plane to louisiana within an hour:

“carol danvers is back.”

they reunite at the rambeau farm. carol hasn’t aged a day, but her face is carved with worry lines and bags under her eyes from sleepless nights.

carol thinks that she is more beautiful than ever.

“what the hell happened?” she asks her soulmate the loaded question, and carol launches into the story of her last 6 years. the kree, her newfound powers, the war, and the lies behind it all.

no one can blame her when she chooses to stay on the ground for this one (“space isn’t ready for me yet!” “sure, babe.”).

she comes back from lawson’s lab with a new purpose and unlocked potential.

she lets her go.

—

the year is 2018. carol has visited a few times throughout the years, but never long enough to settle down.

shield falls. sokovia falls. the avengers fall. again. and again.

half of the world is dust, and according to a trigger-happy raccoon, so is half the universe. 23 days go by. iron man is still missing.

she was tracked down by the avengers when they got back from wakanda, and they took her to their fancy compound upstate. they have fury’s pager there.

her heart sinks. if she hasn’t answered by now, there’s no chance.

but, for once, fate is on her side, and the blessing comes in the form of a beat up spaceship, a genius billionaire playboy philanthropist, a blue alien, and her glowing girl.

she cries out of happiness, and the group of heroes give them space to figure things out.

“i thought you were dead,” she sobs, and she’s drawn into another bone-crushing hug. her soulmate is here, safe, in her arms, and alive. that’s not something many people could say.

“i’m here, i’m here.”

—

the year is 2023. tony stark and natasha romanoff are dead.

she’s numb. she knows what loosing a soulmate can do to a person, and she’s sympathetic to pepper potts and morgan and clint. but she’s numb.

she didn’t know them well. she saw stark in passing, only introduced to him for five minutes before he retired, got married, and had a kid. natasha was a friend (if even). they lived together but barely spoke. they only saw each other when their schedules overlapped (read: never).

she is numb. and carol grounds her.

she is angry. if only a chemist could have saved the world. carol reminds her that not everyone can save the world.

carol reminds her that her world is safe, and standing right next to her.

she doesn’t know how the world will move on. but she knows that she holds her whole universe in her hands.

carol squeezes tighter. her universe.

her universe awaits.

—

tag list:

@defenestrate-yourself-please @limelight20
trail.content:
the universe awaits - c.d.

in which a love story spans 40 years.

pairing: carol danvers x fem!reader

warnings: fluff to angst to fluff. this got long. also a lot of sexism but what did u expect it was the 90’s.

a/n: ah shit. here we go again. another writing challenge, this time a soulmate au! hosted by @mcuspidey ! i hope you guys enjoy!

“what’s a girl like you doin’ in a dump like this?” she’s trying to ignore the creep, with his beer breath and dad bod. she gets him the beer he asked for.

“doin’ my job,” she says, rolling her eyes.

she would’ve quit her job at pancho’s bar years ago, but danny pancho, the owner, was an old family friend, and let her keep the rv out back. nothing like free parking to make a girl stay.

“whatever, frigid bitch. get a real job.” he takes the beer and goes back to his buddies, who eagerly watch the interaction, audible groaning when she turns away and he has a sneer on his face.

sometimes she hates it. sometimes she loves it. and sometimes she wonders if the owner of the jet on her right wrist will ever wander through that door.

the tattoos are on display tonight—the plane on her right wrist, a bubbling erlenmeyer flask on the left. normally, they’re concealed, either by makeup or a flannel, but the day was sweltering and she had run out of concealer.

she occupies herself with wiping down counters—again—when a group storms through the front door, filling the low-volume atmosphere with yelling and laughing. she can only catch snippets of conversation from the group.

“-and the wall? that was-“

“-danvers on the ropes! a joke-“

“-rambeau even doing? no one in-“

“-laughing. like, do they even know-“

they approach the bar top, and her palms are starting to sweat. out of the ten to fifteen young adults, only three are women. not especially promising. with the way that some of the guys are looking at her, she wishes she could run back to the trailer and grab a flannel.

“hey, sweetheart, a round of beers for the guys!” one of them shouts, and she nods, throwing the rag into the sink and moving to the cooler, not sparing a glance at the group.

the beers are distributed and the boys are gone. she turns to the three remaining ladies. “want anything?”

“oh- uh, no, i’m fine-“

“oh, come on, carol. i’m paying. get something.” the oldest of the three chuckles, elbowing the blonde.

“i’m gonna get a beer.” her jacket has rambeau on the lapel—newly stitched. the leather isn’t even worn in.

“well, then, i’ll have the same.” blondie’s jacket is the same, she notices, but with ‘danvers’ written in white lettering.

she nods and grabs the drinks.

“not very talkative, are ya,” danvers asks, taking a swig.

“not really, i guess.” she shruggs. “cool jacket.”

she grins widely and sits a little bit straighter. “officially joined the air force today. that’s why we’re here. celebrating.”

air force. “you a pilot?”

“nah, they don’t let women fly. i wish though.” danvers laughs, glancing down at the bottle in her hands. “maybe someday.”

the conversation stays between the three women. she goes out back, confident that she can leave the bar alone for a few moments. she snags a flannel from her trailer, goosebumps rising on her arms now that the sun has gone down.

as she gets behind the bar, a sound of disappointment comes from the air force guys.

“oh come on, honey. we liked the tank top!”

she ignores them.

danvers rolls her eyes. “johnson thinks he’s hot shit. i think he’s compensating.”

“oh, yeah, he’s totally pissed that he’s not your soulmate,” rambeau replies, catching her attention. “i can still hear his rage from when he saw the flask!”

“flask?” she asks, catching the women, and herself, by surprise. “my mark is an erlenmeyer flask.”

carol soundlessly rolls up her right sleeve, and there it is. dark against her skin. a bubbling erlenmeyer flask matching the one on her left wrist.

“holy shit.”

—

carol danvers is dead.

she’s working at the johnson space center in houston as a chemist (one of three in the lab) when the news arrives in the form of maria and monica rambeau, paying a visit.

the year is 1995. six years since the crash.

her work is monotonous, a distraction to get her through the day, to get her to forget her thoughts.

the thing is, when a person’s soulmate dies, the tattoo burns. it turns white. the black ink against her right wrist serves as a reminder that carol isn’t dead. she’s out there, somewhere, and she isn’t looking for her. she’s just sitting in a lab, playing with chemicals, watching as male coworkers rise through the ranks within months of being hired.

“what the hell happened?” she asks her soulmate the loaded question, and carol launches into the story of her last 6 years. the kree, her newfound powers, the war, and the lies behind it all.

no one can blame her when she chooses to stay on the ground for this one (“space isn’t ready for me yet!” “sure, babe.”).

she lets her go.

the year is 2018. carol has visited a few times throughout the years, but never long enough to settle down.

shield falls. sokovia falls. the avengers fall. again. and again.

—

the year is 2023. tony stark and natasha romanoff are dead.

she’s numb. she knows what loosing a soulmate can do to a person, and she’s sympathetic to pepper potts and morgan and clint. but she’s numb.

she didn’t know them well. she saw stark in passing, only introduced to him for five minutes before he retired, got married, and had a kid. natasha was a friend (if even). they lived together but barely spoke. they only saw each other when their schedules overlapped (read: never).

she is angry. if only a chemist could have saved the world. carol reminds her that not everyone can save the world.

summary: Have u heard about that incel cut of endgame where someone has cut out captain marvel entirely, reduced other womens screen time...
question: Have u heard about that incel cut of endgame where someone has cut out captain marvel entirely, reduced other womens screen time and cut out a lot of black panther too? It's things like this that makes me love captain marvel more.
answer: I did hear about that! My first thought was, dear lord, who has the time to sit there and do that, and my second thought was, I mean, I guess people petty or hateful enough to do that probably don’t have much going on, anyway. So whatever. But yeah, the more dudebros push back against Captain Marvel, the more I love that she exists and that Brie exists and that the middle finger exists.

summary: Brie Larson Praises Stunt Doubles at MTV Movie Awards After Claiming She Did Most of Her Own Stunts for Captain Marvel
title: Brie Larson Praises Stunt Doubles at MTV Movie Awards After Claiming She Did Most of Her Own Stunts for Captain Marvel
body:
Brie Larson Praises Stunt Doubles at MTV Movie Awards After Claiming She Did Most of Her Own Stunts for Captain Marvel

Captain Marvel actress Brie Larson praised her stunt doubles at the MTV Movie Awards after previously claiming she did most of her own stunts for Captain Marvel.

Larson and her stunt doubles Renae Moneymaker and Joanna Bennett took to the MTV Movie Awards stage after Larson won the award for Best Fight.

Larson stated, “This is so cool. First and foremost thank you MTV and thank you to the fans.…
